section.name: First, always follow the JSFUnit Golden Rule: Use Component ID's
section.p: For every JSF component on a page, you have the option of providing a component ID. If you don't provide one, JSF will create one for you. However, if you let JSF create the ID, you will have a hard time referencing the component in your tests. So at least use an ID for any component that you might want to test.

section.name: Create a JSP or Facelets page
Create a JUnit test using the JSFUnit Facade API
Package these jars in your WEB-INF/lib
section.p: First, you will need the JSFUnit jar. Since JSFunit uses JUnit, Cactus, and HttpUnit for much of its infrastructue, you will need at least the minimum jars for these frameworks as well. Don't worry, you won't need to pollute your project with these dependencies. JSFUnit documentation shows how to use Ant or Maven to only include these jars when you are testsing.

Here are the minimum jars you will need in your WEB-INF/lib.
jsfunit-core-1.0-SNAPSHOT.jar (pre-alpha)
aspectjrt-1.2.1.jar
cactus-13-1.7.1.jar
httpunit-1.6.1.jar
junit-3.8.1.jar
nekohtml-0.9.1.jar

section.name: Include cactus-report.xsl in the root of your WAR
Deploy your application and run the tests.
section.p:
Deploy your JSF application to your favorite server. Then, type something like the following URL into your browser to run the tests:
http://localhost:8080/myjsfapp/ServletTestRunner?suite=com.foo.JSFUnitTest&xsl=cactus-report.xsl

section.name: Running JSFUnit tests as part of your build.
section.p: After you see how to run JSFunit tests from a browser, you will probably want to integrate JSFUnit as part of your build and part of a true Test-Driven Development process. We will be documenting this soon, but you can probably figure it out on your own if you look at the Cactus documentation here.
Since the JSFUnit infrastructure is based on Apache Cactus, you set up your tests exactly the same way as Cactus. The only difference is that you use the filter declaration as shown above.
